title: Humanizing product development | Adriel Frederick (Reddit, Lyft, Facebook)
key_insights: Focus on marginal users (those on the cusp of taking desired actions) to identify and fix product problems that affect broader user adoption
Growth hacking requires fundamental product value - tactics alone won't sustain growth without solving real user problems
Product managers must design the interface between algorithms and human decision-making, not rely solely on automated systems
Diversity provides concrete business value by enabling teams to understand global users without extensive research
When facing controversy, distinguish between valid criticism and resistance to change by staying close to users
Leadership requires shifting from individual contributor skills to organization design and empathy
Successful growth comes from grinding on core actions (finding product, getting in, finding friends) rather than seeking silver bullets
R&D teams must feel core to the mission and create shared success to avoid organizational rejection

guest_background.current_role: VP of Product Management at Reddit X

topics_discussed: Reddit X team and evolving interaction modes
NFT marketplace for digital art creators
Setting up R&D teams in large organizations
Impact of diverse background on product development
Being the first Black PM at Facebook
Pricing and marketplace dynamics at Lyft
Origins and reality of growth hacking
Facebook's growth strategies and friend recommendations
The famous '10 friends in 14 days' metric
Experimentation success rates and portfolio management
Transition from IC to leadership roles
Organization design and empathy in leadership
memorable_quotes: When you are working on algorithmic heavy products, your job is figuring out what the algorithm should be responsible for, what people are responsible for, and the framework for making decisions.

You have to have your teams look like the world, it just makes you so much faster. It's not perfect. You still have to go out and talk to folks because we still have our own kind of monocultures that form that we need to get out of. But it helps a lot.

The hardest part of empathy is taking my own shoes off. Basically going, Yo, okay, I came into this, there's something I wanted, I wanted to get rid of that. Now just talk to this person and try to understand what's going on with them.
frameworks_mentioned: Growth experimentation portfolio (cannonballs vs lead bullets)
recommended_for: Professionals interested in diversity and inclusion
summary: Adriel Frederick shares battle-tested insights from scaling products at Facebook, Lyft, and Reddit, covering everything from growth strategies and algorithmic product design to leadership development and the business value of diversity. The conversation provides practical frameworks for product managers working on growth, marketplace dynamics, and the transition from individual contributor to organizational leader.
